title: Can you declare chapter 7 if you have 100k in equity , debt is 14,500. Low income perm disabled works pt time, no retirement ,
question: Nothing just my home
answers:
Can you declare bankruptcy? Always a yes, however whether it is wise and you will not be dismissed is another question. I like to evaluate potential cases in the following manor:
1. do you qualify based upon your income and family size?
2. Have you filed a prior bankruptcy within 8 years?
3. How much debt do you have and does that make a bankruptcy worth it compared to your income.
4. Finally, will you have to forfeit any assets at all?

Speak with a licensed professional to address these concerns.
How much equity you can protect is dependent on which exemption set you use. Others have discussed the exemption amounts. It's likely you can protect all of the equity. Best of luck!

I assume that the $100,000 equity that you are talking about is equity in your home. If that is correct, there are 4 possibilities.

1) If you are "disabled" you could protect $175,000 in equity in your home. What concerns me is the statement that "works pt ti.me" There are a lot of potential issues. You may or may not be able to use that $175,000 disability exemption.

2) You may still be able to use the $175,000 exemption if you are over 55 years old AND you have a limited amount of income.

3) If you have other people living with you (spouse / dependents) you may be able to protect $100,000 in equity in the home.

4) If you don't qualify for any of those you would still have a $75,000 exemption.

All this presumes that this property is where you live. Also it presumes that you have lived in CA at least 2 years (otherwise you may NOT qualify to use CA exemptions.)

The biggest concern I have is that you may not know the exact value of you home. It could be more than the exemption allows or it may reach that while your case is open, in which case the bankruptcy trustee could sell the home and give the exempt amount to you and pay the creditors with the difference.

There is something I call the "shadow exemption." that is where the equity is more than the exempt amount but less than the trustee could get selling the house AFTER cost of sale is considered.

I would suggest that you get a REAL, HONEST APPRAISAL.

If the equity is close to the allowed exemption, you may need to do a "motion to compel the trustee to abandon the home back to you.

You may be able to keep your home only to lose vehicles or other assets. Without detailed information that a bankruptcy attorney will get from you, no one can tell you all your rights and options (like Chapter 13 if Chapter 7 is not going to work.

There are many other risks and potential issues that are way beyond what can be covered here.

I agree with the other attorneys who say that you must find a highly qualified bankruptcy attorney. Most attorneys will give you are free initial consultation.

You can look at the Avvo dot com ratings. Choose the best rated ones.

You could also look at the CA State bar website for a Certified Bankruptcy Law Specialist in Sacramento. I have provided a link to the state bar below.

Another potential source for finding a good attorney would be through a search of the National Association of Consumer Bankruptcy Attorneys (NACBA.org) to find a good local attorney. Again, I have provided a link below.

There is a new ratings website that ranks over 70 different "top rated Sacramento bankruptcy attorneys" using a number of different criteria. The link is below as well.

You need quality advice as your can easily step on a land mine you don't know about. This is your home that is on the line.

You can certainly file a Chapter 7, but you probably should not, at least not on your own. Please consult with an experienced local bankruptcy attorney. You need to have someone review all the facts in your case and provide experienced legal judgment before filing any bankruptcy. If you have that much equity, you can not afford a mistake that will arise from trying to do this yourself.

You can always declare Chapter 7 bankruptcy, the questions to ask are whether you are eligible for a discharge in the Chapter 7 bankruptcy and what property can you protect if you file a Chapter 7 bankruptcy. You don't specifically state what asset it is that has "100k in equity," however, whether the equity is in your home (as I suspect) or in a combination of other assets, you should speak to a knowledgeable consumer bankruptcy attorney. The attorney will look at whether a homestead was declared properly if you are dealing with real property and whether you are eligible for the homestead exemption, and will be able to look at what other exemption will be of benefit to you. Also, if a Chapter 7 bankruptcy is not in your best interest, the attorney would be able to discuss alternatives with you (such as a Chapter 13 bankruptcy).

Yes. You may file BK. Real question is whether you will exempt and protect "100k in equity".
If you are concerned with protecting "100k in equity" in your primary residence, you have options to choose from.
CALIFORNIA SET #1
HOMESTEAD IN A PRIMARY RESIDENCE—C.C.P. § 704.730
The amount of this exemption is:
$75,000 for a single person
$100,000 for a married person OR a head of household
$175,000 for a person 65 years or older OR a physically or mentally disabled person, OR a person 55 years or older with an income of less than $25,000 (or $35,000 if a married couple).
To qualify for the homestead exemption, the property must be the principal residence of the debtor or the debtor’s spouse. The Bankruptcy Code now also requires that a person is only entitled to a maximum homestead of $125,000 until such time as they have lived in that state for approximately 3.4 years. (This will obviously only relate to those claiming the larger $175,000 homestead amount.)
The exemption is for equity in the property. For exemption purposes, equity is determined by taking the fair market value of the property and subtracting the value of any consensual liens (mortgages and deeds of trust).
or
CALIFORNIA SET #2
REAL PROPERTY—C.C.P. § 703.140(b)(1)A
$24060 exemption in real property (including a mobile home) is allowed if used as a primary residence or burial plot.plus
WILD CARD—C.C.P. § 703.140(b)(5)
The “wild card” can exempt $1,280, plus any unused portion of the $24,060 exemption listed above, in
any asset. In other words, if a person does not claim an exemption in a primary residence, they have a $25,340 exemption that they can claim in any assets.

What is your $100k in equity? A house? A car? If its in your house, you might be able to protect it depending on other factors. If you're low income, its likely that you will qualify for bankruptcy, but there are lots of other factors to consider. Most bankruptcy attorneys will meet with you for a free consultation. I would advise you sit down and speak with a qualified attorney.
